podcast_summary: ‚Äì Bob Ross was an American artist best known for his landscapes, but he's also known for having a thing for fish. And now his work is on display at the Lyndon B. Johnson Presidential Library in Chicago. The exhibit, called New Age Strategies for Survival, is the first time Ross' paintings have been on display in the US, reports the Chicago Tribune. They're also the first Ross' paintings to be loaned out to a presidential library. The exhibit was announced by the DePaul Art Museum, which describes it as "a celebration of the power of the human spirit to change the way we think and feel about the world." The show runs through Nov. 10.

podcast_summary: ‚Äì The Boston Celtics are off to a fast start in the NBA this season, but they're not off to a great start by any means. The team is off to a 2-0 start for the first time since the 2007-08 season, reports the Boston Globe, which notes that the Celts have won their first two games by an average of 18.3 points. That includes a 107-107 win over the Philadelphia 76ers on Saturday night in which the Celtics led by 11 points at the end of the third quarter and by 10 at the end of the fourth. The AP notes that the Celts are the only team in the league that hasn't lost by more than 10 points in the first two games.

show name: The Soap Box with Austin Malleolo
episode name: What is wrong with how we talk about NUTRITION?
creator description: In this episode I talk about a problem I have seen creeping into the world of Nutrition space and it is how we talk about other types of diets. There are MANY ways to eat an ways to get to results and many are based on your goals as well. In this episode I talk about HOW we have gone wrong with going in the other direction and vilifying other types of diets that are not "YOURS" and how this is dangerous and overall counterproductive to helping others. Take a listen and chill the heck out! ¬†

show_name: The Soap Box with Austin Malleolo
show_description: We step onto the soap box about any given topic and don‚Äôt step off until it‚Äôs exhausted. From CrossFit to business to relationships to training and coaching we cover it all. We will try to keep the episodes to around 20 minutes. Let us know what you want to hear, and we will cover it! You will love it or hate it, but we will go all in no matter what and not hold back! Topics include; CrossFit, Coaching, Competing, Business, Finance, Parenting, Travel, Relationships, Nutrition, Leadership and more!

podcast_summary: ‚Äì If you're looking to bulk up for your next workout, there's a new diet plan you may want to try. It's called the Zone, and it's designed for people who want to lose weight but don't want to go on a strict paleo-like diet, the New York Daily News reports. According to a press release, the Zone‚Äîwhich was first published in the CrossFit Journal in 2014‚Äîis designed to get people to their goal weight in less than two weeks. The main difference between the Zone and the paleo diet is that the paleo diet emphasizes whole, natural foods, while the Zone focuses on refined carbs and sugars, the Daily News reports. According to the Zone's website, the main difference between the two diets is that the paleo diet emphasizes whole, natural foods, while the Zone focuses on refined carbs and sugars. According to the Zone, the main difference between the two diets is that the paleo diet emphasizes whole, natural foods, while the Zone focuses on refined carbs and sugars. On a recent podcast, the creator of the Zone said the Zone taught him "how to turn my body into a laboratory" and that he doesn't think the Zone is the diet for everybody.

podcast_summary: ‚Äì It's not every day that a true-crime podcast gets picked up by Oprah Winfrey, but that's exactly what happened in Colombia. Suspiria, hosted by Patricia Arquette and starring Patricia Arquette, was picked up by Winfrey's production company last month, the New York Daily News reports. It's a true-crime podcast about crime in South America, according to its website, and Arquette says she wanted to do something "that is not drug-related for like, you know, the first time Colombian case because like you search Latin American to you only get Pablo Escobar basically." The show's website says it's based on articles from the Washington Post, the BBC, and the New York Times, among others, and that it's "about the criminal justice system in South America, the political system in South America, the economic system in South America, and the human rights system in South America." The first episode of the show was released in October, and on the show's Facebook page, Arquette says it's "very exciting" to be a part of it. "I'm so honored to be a part of it," she says. "I've always wanted to be a part of this

"So we've decided to make a podcast for we talk about Pokemon a lot of Pokemon." The first two episodes are out Tuesday, and the third will be out Nov. 12. Among the topics they'll touch on: the evolution of Pokemon, their favorite gyms, and more. "We debate their strengths weaknesses," Griffin says. "We discuss which ones are ugly and have weird growths liked Angela. Huh? And which ones are very handsome like growly."

podcast_summary: ‚Äì "I'm not losing anything. I'm cool with no one else that you think and I'm okay with know what I think about myself and I'm comfortable with know what I think about myself." That's what YouTube star and self-described "fattest woman on the planet" Lisa Symons says on her podcast, which has racked up more than a million subscribers since it was launched in August, reports People. But the 36-year-old Real Housewives of New York City star, who has appeared on shows including Dancing With the Dweebs and Real Housewives of Beverly Hills, says she's not quite there yet. "Right now today I and it's a process. It's something like anything. It's good and it's worth it," she says. "But it is very possible. You take small steps, you know, I think initially something very very important is to change your mindset change how you think about things change how you feel about things change how you process things change how you process things when we can. Be slow to take and quick to give because we're comfortable with knowing whatever happens. You're not losing anything."

podcast_summary: ‚Äì Taco Bell's latest snack craze is ... something. Eater reports the fast-food chain is testing out a "Gummy Gummy" snack that's basically a bag of gummy vitamins with a twist. It's being called "Gummy Smacks," and it's being billed as a snack that's "smooth and sweet" and "fun to eat." Taco Bell isn't the only company trying to cash in on the trend: gummy vitamins are also being sold by Whole Foods and Trader Joe's, according to BuzzFeed.

podcast_summary: ‚Äì Wisconsin's University of Wisconsin-Madison rowing team won the NCAA title last year for the third time in four years, and the team's coach says he's "thrilled and honored" to have the team back in the title game after a one-year absence. "It's been a long time since we've been back in the title game, and I'm just so proud of the team and how they've handled themselves on and off the field over the last couple of years," says head coach Paul Chryst, per the AP. "I'm just so proud of them. They've worked so hard. I'm just so proud of them." Chryst says he doesn't think the team will be able to repeat last year's success, but he's optimistic about this year's team. "I think we're going to be just as good as last year," he says. "I think we're going to go to the World Cup. I think we're going to get to the Super Bowl. I think we're going to be just as good as last year."

podcast_summary: ‚Äì It's not every day that a Twitter user posts a photo of himself in a Darth Vader costume, but that's exactly what happened to Elliot Turnbull on Sunday. The British comedian, who goes by Elliot Turnbull on Twitter, posted a photo of himself decked out as the villain from the Lord of the Rings on Instagram with the caption, "This is what it looks like when I'm wearing a Darth Vader costume." It quickly went viral, with many commenters pointing out the resemblance to the villain from the Lord of the Rings, Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King, and even Lord of the Rings: The Battle of the Five Armies. (It's not clear if the photo was taken during a match, or was simply posted to Instagram.) "I think it's pretty funny," Turnbull tells the Guardian. "It's funny when you're in a costume and you're wearing a costume and people are just like, 'Oh, you look like a Lord of the Rings character,'" he says. podcast_summary: ‚Äì It's not your usual dish of the week: Radiolab's Adam Davidson went on a trip to New York City and chowed down on a pigeon, which he describes as "a small bird without a lot of meat in a very very distinct taste and texture that's not going to appeal to everybody that small bird." He calls it "a little bloody" and "a little grossed out," but adds, "You hate it almost wallet. I'm going to swallow it." Davidson talks to historian Sarah Lomond, a cook and a historian, about the dish, which was on the first menu at the French restaurant Delmonico in the 1830s. It was served with green peas and "this menu item pigeon with game" coloring, she explains. The story goes back to a young sociology professor at NYU named Colin Jarrell Mac, who wanted to be "just like his hero Jane Jacobs," Davidson explains. Jarrell Mac started taking notes on what people were doing in Greenwich Village's Father Demos Square, and the project grew from there. podcast_summary: ‚Äì In 1969, astronauts placed a time capsule in the foundation of the Mark Evans Observatory on the campus of Illinois Wesleyan University. Fifty years later, it's being dug up. The Chicago Tribune reports that a time capsule placed in 1969 by Apollo 8 astronauts Frank Borman and Frank Borman has been unearthed in the foundation of the observatory. The astronauts placed a letter in the time capsule that said, "I hope I will be this proud and prestigious of an institution then as it is now, you know some goofy sentimental ship." Wesleyan student Terrell Wilson was one of the astronauts who placed the time capsule in 1969 and has been advocating for it to be dug up for years on the school's podcast, Wesley Stars. Wilson told the Tribune last year that he hoped the time capsule would hold confidential files that prove the moon landing was faked. NASA staged the time capsule for a movie in order to get the country excited for the moon landing, he said. "If we're up there chilling on the moon with a can of beer and a lawn chair before the Russians, it'll make us look super cool and take the Public's mind off the crazy world that we live pictures of old students," he said at the time.

But if you're Nana Sharma, you've heard of Paultalks, a podcast that's been viewed more than 6 million times and counting since it was launched in September. And if you're a parent, you've probably heard of it, too. "My goal is to try and keep this podcast as exciting and humorous as possible while hopefully also making you feel like you're not alone in this absolutely crazy life and that there's someone out there who actually understands," Sharma says on the show's website, per People. podcast_summary: ‚Äì Paula Deen is back on the Today show, but this time she's not talking about her famous past. Instead, she's talking about her new album, appropriately titled Paula Deen's Greatest hits, Rolling Stone reports. In an interview with Matt Lauer yesterday, Deen said her upcoming album will be her first in 13 years. "It's going to be something that I've never done before," she said. "It's going to be something that I've never heard before. It's going to be something that I've never seen before. It's going to be a record that I've never heard before." She added, however, that the album won't be out until next year.

show_description: The best part of the fountain pen community is just that, the community. And the ultimate experience is spending time after the pen show wraps for the day sitting at the bar with all the other pen nerds talking pens, ink and paper. We want to capture that spirit of the ‚Äúpen show after dark‚Äù - so in this podcast, swearing is encouraged and we‚Äôre probably drinking while recording. It is definitely NSFW. Enjoy and thanks for hanging with us!

show_description: Monica Yates is a ICF Women's Life & Period Coach. Her no BS approach is loved by her Instagram fam and clients.   In these episodes, Monica will be talking about all things periods, the female cycle, vaginas, hormones, confidence, health, food, fitness, our brains, boys and all the stuff that no one seems to talk about, but everyone is thinking.   Monica is real, down to heart and fu*king honest with her approach.   Grab the popcorn, and enjoy!  You can find Monica... @monicayateshealth  YouTube: Monica Yates monicayates.com.au *This is not designed to diagnose, treat or prevent disease

podcast_summary: ‚Äì It's not every day that a podcaster goes on a rant about her menstrual cycle, but that's exactly what happened to Hearts Mauna Kea, a self-described "woman's life coach" who's made a name for herself on Instagram for her frank talk on everything from "vaginas hormones" to "feminism in the 21st century." Now she's been fired from her job after a video of her rant went viral, People reports. In the video, which has since been removed from Instagram, the 26-year-old from Hawaii can be heard ranting that she's "never had a period in my life" and that her period was "a gift from God" that she wants to share with the rest of the world. After the video went viral last week, she was let go from her job as a clinical social worker at a clinic that specializes in women's health because she violated the company's terms of service, the New York Daily News reports. In a statement, the clinic said it "does not condone this behavior" and that "Ms. Mauna Kea has been fired from her position as a social worker for violating the company's terms of service." podcast_summary: ‚Äì The latest drama to hit the cast of TLC's Real World/Road Rules Challenge reality show: Kalani Astra's mom, Debbie, is speaking out about domestic abuse she says she suffered at the hands of her son-in-law, Kalani's husband, Colt. In a post on AfterBuzz reality TV, Debbie says she was inspired to speak out after watching a fan debate on social media about Angela Mills, Kalani's ex-wife and fellow cast member on Real World/Road Rules Challenge, hitting on Angela for allegedly hitting her husband, Michael. Debbie, who says she was divorced from Michael when he married Kalani, went on to say that male domestic violence is an "epidemic" and that female domestic abuse should be pursued no matter what the charges are. podcast_summary: ‚Äì If you're an 8-year-old girl in the UK, chances are you've heard of Migo, the animated character from the Netflix series Stranger Things. If you're not, well, an 8-year-old girl in the UK, chances are you've never heard of Migo, the animated character from Netflix's Stranger Things. The character, voiced by Millie Bobby Brown, first appeared in the first season of Netflix's Stranger Things, which was released in 2015. Migo was created to help 8-year-olds learn more about Stranger Things, and in a recent interview with the Telegraph, Brown explained why she thinks it's such a great idea. "I think it's such a brilliant idea," she says. "I think it's a great way for 8-year-olds to learn about the world. I think it's such a brilliant way for people to learn about the world. I think it's such a great way for people to learn about themselves. I think it's such a great way for people to learn about themselves."

podcast_summary: ‚Äì It's not every day that a podcast called "Bible at bedtime" goes viral, but that's exactly what happened this week. The popular podcast by Amber Lawton, who says she enjoys listening to the Bible to help her fall asleep, got a lot of attention this week after Lawton shared a dream dreamed up by 17-year-old Joseph. In the dream, Joseph says he was working with his brothers on a sheep farm when he had a dream. "Suddenly my Sheaf stood up and your sheaves gathered around it and bow down to my Sheaf," he says. "Are you really going to rule us? So they hated him even more because of his dream and what he had said." The brothers then stripped off Joseph's robe, threw him into a pit, and ate a meal when a caravan of lights came from Ishmael's field. Lawton posted the dream on her Facebook page Tuesday, and it's been shared more than 5,600 times. "This is a dream. This is a story. This is what the Bible says," she writes. "It's not a hoax. It's real. And it's important. And it's true. And it's good. And it's true."

podcast_summary: ‚Äì It's not every day that a cable news host gets fired, but that's exactly what happened to Bill O'Reilly this week. The Fox News host was let go from his gig as co-host of The O'Reilly Factor after just two years on the air, the New York Daily News reports. "It's with a lot of sadness that we have decided to part ways," says a statement from Fox News. "Bill has been an important part of The O'Reilly Factor for the past two years and we wish him the best in the future." O'Reilly had been a fixture on Fox News for years, hosting his own show on the network and appearing regularly on Sean Hannity's show. He was also a co-host of The O'Reilly Factor before that, and hosted his own show on the Fox Business Network before that. He was also a contributor to Fox News before that, and hosted his own show on the Fox Business Network before that. But he was fired after less than a year on the air. The Daily News notes that it's not clear whether O'Reilly was fired because of his show's success or because he was unhappy with the network.

podcast_summary: ‚Äì Taylor Swift's latest headline-grabbing move: She's going to ban nudity in her concerts, at least for the time being. In a statement, Swift said she'd made the decision after "careful consideration" and "after much discussion" with her family and friends. "As a result, I have decided to remove nudity from my concerts for the time being," she wrote. "I have also decided to postpone the release of my new album 'Bad Blood' until further notice." She added that she'd be "delighted" to do so in a way that "serves as a reminder to all of us that we have the power to make the world a better place." podcast_summary: ‚Äì The Dallas Mavericks beat the Orlando Magic on Monday night, but not in the way you'd expect. With the score tied in the final seconds, Orlando's Arron Afflalo missed a potential game-winning three-point shot, and Dallas' Dirk Nowitzki grabbed the rebound. The Magic had a chance to win in the final seconds, but Orlando's Elfrid Payton couldn't get off a shot at the buzzer, the Dallas Morning News reports. "It was a weird game," Nowitzki said after the game. "I'd buy them because they weren't it's not like they played exceptionally because they kept Jonathan Isaac, but they kept fighting and it's like it's over your season's over. podcast_summary: ‚Äì A Native American high priestess in Minnesota has died at the age of 73, the Pioneer Press reports. According to the Minneapolis Star Tribune, Yonder Kaur, also known as Yonder the Elder, was found dead of a heart attack in her home in St. Paul on Saturday. She had been missing for more than a week. Kaur, who was born in India, was a high priestess in the Akta Alliance of Religions, a community of roughly 7,000 people from all over the world who believe they are connected to the creator. According to the Star Tribune, the Akta Alliance was founded in the 1970s by a group of Native American women who believed they were connected to the creator. In addition to being a high priestess, Kaur was known for being a healer, a teacher, and an advocate for Native American women. According to the Star Tribune, Kaur's death was announced by the Akta Alliance in a Facebook post on Sunday. "Yonder has been gone from this earth for more than a week now," the post reads. "Please keep her in your prayers."

Ed also discusses his celebrated career at BET, where he became the face of the entertainment network‚Äôs once prominent news coverage. podcast_summary: ‚Äì If you've ever wanted to know what it was like to be a human centipede, well, you're in luck. It turns out the centipede was created by a small creature called a centipede. In a podcast called "My Neighbors Are Dead," composer Phim Jesse case explains the origin of the centipede, which he calls "probably the birth of where today's character came from," per the Chicago Tribune. Jesse case, who plays Vagner on the popular Netflix series Stranger Things, says the idea for the centipede first came to him while he was working on a show for a Chicago comedy theater. "We got to throw," he says. "Ourselves into Germany and German classical music and I think that was probably the birth of where today's character came from."

podcast_summary: ‚Äì It's not every day a boxer gets the chance to fight for Australia, but that's exactly what happened to Jack Bowen on Saturday. The 23-year-old, who was born in Queensland and grew up in a working-class neighborhood in Melbourne, went into the ring to take on New Zealand's Danny Williams for the vacant World Boxing Council International welterweight title in Brisbane, reports the BBC. It was a huge step up for Bowen, who was already a two-time Australian Amateur Boxing Association champion and a two-time Australian Football League champion with the Western Bulldogs. But it was a big step down for Williams, who lost his world title to Joseph Parker in 2015 and was last year stripped of his WBO world title for failing to submit in the 10th round, per the Guardian. "I was a bit disappointed," Williams tells the BBC. "It was a good fight, but he's a world champion, so I was expecting a good fight." Bowen, however, wasn't expecting such a big step up. He started boxing at the age of 13 after getting injured while playing AFL, and "it can get a bit full-on sometimes and just to have a balance with mates playing a team sport as well was good," he told

Hosted by GMat, he brings along his two friends (Aidan and Ben) on a journey of stories, experiences and segments that often end in all three wheezing with laughter. Can Australians stay on topic? Aidan O'Brien, who started the show with Matt Selman in 2012, was sentenced to prison on Oct. 29 after prosecutors determined he had violated his probation by using a firearm during the commission of a felony, according to a press release. podcast_summary: ‚Äì Northern Mullen, a flute player with The Moody Blues, has a message for the world: Thank you. In an episode of her podcast called Gratitude Seekers, Mullen shares the story of her father, who died of Alzheimer's in 2013, and the song "This Beautiful World," which she wrote for him. "I wrote and played everything that you hear in this song nor does first intention was to send it as a token of appreciation for me for the podcast, but after listening to it, I knew that I must I share it with you the Gratitude Seekers It's a Beautiful song written and recorded by a fellow gratitude speaker that can really help you connect with this wonderful feeling of gratitude," she writes. Mullen, who lives in England, says she's been listening to the podcast since 2017 and was moved by its focus on gratitude. "I feel for the work you're doing thank you for making the world a better place and please continue being awesome," she writes. "I want to thank you. You're not alone."

podcast_summary: ‚Äì An up-and-coming rapper was arrested last week for allegedly using stolen credit card numbers on his own music. Jonathan Woods, real name Jonathan Woods, was charged with aggravated identity theft, wire fraud, and unauthorized use of a credit card, the Los Angeles Times reports. The 25-year-old rapper, whose real name is Brendan Corral, was arrested after he allegedly used a stolen credit card number on two of his own songs, TMZ reports. In one song, he rapped that he "made a Killin I made 10 and have to split it and then he's got a bunch your Instagram posts of all his money bunch of credit cards got like a fake gold credit card chain." In another, he rapped that he used a stolen credit card number on a song he wrote for Nicki Minaj. According to prosecutors, Corral used the stolen credit card number to make over $100,000 in charges on two different credit cards. The charges carry maximum sentences of five years in prison, a $250,000 fine, or both, the Times reports. Prosecutors say Corral used the stolen credit card number to make purchases at Walmart and Bed Bath & Beyond, among other places. Corral has been released on bail.

It's a big game for both teams, as the 49ers are trying to stay in the NFL's playoffs and the Vikings are trying to avoid being knocked out in the first round for the second year in a row. Here's what you need to know: The New York Times has a profile of the 49ers' Jerry Rice, who is the league's all-time leading scorer with 2,936 goals. Rice, who played for the 49ers from 1980 to 1984, is one of the most popular players in the league, and the Times says he's "one of the most popular athletes in the NFL." He's the league's all-time leading scorer with 2,936 goals, and the league's all-time leading scorer with 521 assists. He's also the league's all-time leading scorer by a margin of at least one goal, and the league's all-time leading scorer by a margin of at least one assist. show_description: It's time for practical personal development! In just two minutes every day you can hear a new self-improvement tip that will help you get more out of your time, energy, and effort.   Hosted by TedX Speaker Brian Ford, inch closer to your potential by opening your mind to new opportunities for personal growth!   Give your first episode a try and see what we're talking about! episode_description: Do you want to create a new habit? Try using a different habit as a trigger!
full_transcript: Hey, this is Brian Ford from self-improvement daily optimizing your personal development one tip at a time. Today's tip comes from Jake Jordan the host of the unlearned show and he's talking about how habits can be anchored with previous habits. If you ever wanted to try something new but just have a hard time staying on track. Well, I learned a tip the years back from a guest who showed me how I could add a new habit to my list every week if I wanted to when they'll be amazing if you could eat.Click add something to your life. It would help improve you well, I'm not going to hold out any longer. The tip is called anchoring and you may have seen it and the show Sherlock Sherlock Holmes has what he calls a mind Palace and he can go through and find pieces of information really just by closing his eyes and remembering things but it's actually far less complex than that. All you have to do is Anchor the new habit to an old habit that you've already got down. Let me give you a quick example. I brush my teeth every day. Day, hopefully you do too, but I wanted to start flossing more often. So I made sure that I had something to Foss with by my toothbrush and I made a commitment to myself that every time I picked up my toothbrush. I would also floss. So guess what? I started flossing more. So why don't you go out and try anchoring a new habit to an old one and make a new one today. Thanks. Jake great tip and thank you for listening to self-improvement daily.
podcast_summary: ‚Äì If you've ever tried to start a new habit and just couldn't keep it up, there's a tip for you. It's called "anchoring," and it works like this: Instead of trying to start a new habit, just stick with the one that's already in place. For example, if you want to start flossing, you should make a commitment to yourself that you'll Floss every time you pick up your toothbrush. And if you want to start brushing your teeth, you should make a commitment to Floss every time you pick up your toothbrush. So, as self-improvement expert Brian Ford explains on his website, "I made sure that I had something to Foss with by my toothbrush and I made a commitment to myself that every time I picked up my toothbrush. So guess what? I started flossing more."

show_description: Welcome to The Garyvee Audio Experience, hosted by entrepreneur, CEO, investor, vlogger, and public speaker Gary Vaynerchuk. On this podcast you'll find a mix of my #AskGaryVee show episodes, keynote speeches on marketing and business, segments from my WEEKLYVEE video series, interviews and fireside chats I've given, as well as new and current thoughts I record originally for this audio experience!

podcast_summary: ‚Äì The co-founder and CEO of LinkedIn, one of the world's most popular business networking sites, has been arrested in Chattanooga, Tenn., for allegedly making threats against the city's mayor and police chief, the Chattanooga Times Free Press reports. According to the New York Daily News, 44-year-old LinkedIn co-founder Brenton Immelt was arrested Wednesday on a misdemeanor charge of making a terrorist threat. Police say Immelt made the threats on Facebook, Twitter, and in an email to Chattanooga Police Chief Randall Brackins, threatening to kill the mayor and police chief if they didn't shut down the city's social media accounts, according to the Times Free Press. Immelt, who was born and raised in New York, moved to Chattanooga five years ago and co-founded LinkedIn in 2014. He was arrested for allegedly making similar threats against the mayor of San Francisco and police chief of Oakland, Calif., last year.

podcast_summary: ‚Äì If you're in the UK and looking to boost your chances of getting a high school diploma, here's some advice: Don't take your exam until you're at least 16 years old. That's the age at which students are required to be in school, and a new law in the UK is making it even harder for young people to get their diploma, the New York Times reports. That's because students who don't pass their exam by the age of 16 can't get their diploma if they're still in high school. That means that if you want to get a job in the UK, you'll have to take the exam before you turn 16, even if you're already in high school. The law is called the Lifelong Learning Act, and it's designed to make it easier for young people to find jobs in the UK, the Times notes. The law was introduced in the House of Commons last week, and it's expected to become law in the Senate as soon as next month, according to the Times. It's not clear how many students will be affected by the law, but the Times notes that it's "likely to be a major factor in how many jobs are created in the

podcast_summary: ‚Äì The San Diego State Aztecs are off to the best start in program history, having won their first 13 games of the season, the AP reports. And they're off to a pretty good start in the Mountain West, too, with a 9-1 record so far in conference play. But things don't get much better for the Aztecs on the court, where they've lost their last two games by a total of six points. That includes a buzzer-beater by the New Mexico State Aggies last week in which San Diego State's Trey Wetzel stole the ball from a Aggies player near the end of the game and raced the length of the court for a dunk that put the Aztecs up by four with two seconds left, the AP reports. "It was a great feeling," Wetzel said after the game, per the San Diego Union-Tribune. "It was just a matter of getting the win."

podcast_summary: ‚Äì If you're sitting in front of the TV all day and don't get out of it, here's a tip for you: Move every 30 minutes. That's what celebrity personal trainer Jim Quick, who's behind the "quick brain challenge," tells Today.com. As your body moves, it "actually stimulates brain-derived neurotropic factors, which is like fertilizer for your brain and helps create new brain cells and new connections," he explains. "So you have to challenge yourself physically and so we Encourage you to move every 30 minutes and one of the things you could do to get that activity in is learning how to juggle."

podcast_summary: ‚Äì The Philadelphia Eagles' quarterback situation just got a lot worse. ESPN's Adam Kaplan calls it "Widespread Panic All Over the Delaware Valley" in a podcast with Adam Kaplan of Inside the Birds, noting that backup Nate Sudfeld is out for the season with a left wrist fracture. It's a big setback for the Eagles, who were already thin at the position with two-year starter Carson Wentz out with a knee injury and signed free agent Cody Kessler in the offseason. But it's not all bad news for the team. ESPN's Ian Rapoport calls the Eagles "one of the most intriguing teams in the NFL" in a separate podcast with Rapoport. He notes that they're rumored to be interested in free-agent QB Colin Kaepernick, who has said he wants to sit during the national anthem this season to protest racial injustice.

podcast_summary: ‚Äì It's not every day you get the chance to sit down with a radio host and discuss his or her favorite rap songs, but that's exactly what happened to Canada's Kane Brown. In an interview with Power 103.7 in Toronto, the host asked him what his favorite rap song is. "I don't really have a top like an actual order to my top 10 but I love this song," he replied. "I do like this song that with you my top 10 rap songs. I don't really have it though. That's what I'm saying. I'm just saying like this would probably be in the top 10 if I was thinking about it." (Listen to the full interview here.) He went on to explain that he didn't grow up with rap because he only got into it in the last decade. "I didn't grow up with it," he said. "You got a lot of music to go through the documentary series where they look at the origins of rap music totally. It's kind of cool just to get a brief history of all that just like it's cool to get a brief history of any music."

podcast_summary: ‚Äì If you've ever wished you could be more than just your best self, now's your chance. "Today I choose happiness. Today in this moment. I will allow good energy to flow today. I will help someone grow today. I will be the best version of myself." So writes Marcel Cornett on his blog, and it's one of 300 affirmations he shares on his spoken with gratitude podcast, per the Huffington Post. "Today I choose love over hate. Energy, that does not serve. My purpose is not welcome," Cornett writes. "I am so thankful for what I've experienced. I am learning more and more about myself. Today like everyday I am learning more and more about myself. Today I choose to change my thinking from I can't to I can I am surrounded by the right people in my life today. I declare that I am worthy today. I know my worth. I know my value I deserve to be valued and appreciated today patients will serve my purpose. Today I will be more patient. I am open to learning new things. I will no longer work for anyone other than myself."

episode name: Cancer Is The Ultimate Equalizer with Annie Bond
creator description: Everything you thought you knew about cancer was wrong. Fuck.¬† Annie Bond is on our show today, a talented comedian (and dog owner) who was diagnosed with Stage 4 breast cancer at 26. Apparently you can do everything right and still get breast cancer?! Annie talks about navigating the American healthcare system (surprise, it's impossible), dealing with the loss of friends and how a look-a-like Bernie Sanders helped saved her life. To follow Annie on her journey or to see her next improve show, head over to her¬†Instagram @TheAnnieBond If you enjoyed this episode, please leave us a review on your favorite podcast platform and remember to follow us on¬†Instagram¬†and¬†Facebook¬†to stay up to date on everything Heavy Topics!¬†@HeavyTopics

quasi-supervised summary: Sunderland's Takeover of the club could be done as early as Monday. Northern United draw 3-1 away at Accrington Stanley. Sam Allardyce could be set for a return to the club. New Netflix series to be revealed. And all the build-up to the weekend trip to bottom Wanderers.
supervised summary: The Sunderland Echo's SAFC team are back with a brand new podcast this week, and this week Phil Smith, Mark Donnelly and James Copley are joined by Micky Lough as they discuss the latest takeover news and preview this weekend's trip to bottom-
show_description: A weekly Sunderland AFC podcast bringing you - the fans - all the latest news, views, insight and debate.  Featuring Sunderland Echo writers Phil Smith, Richard Mennear, Mark Donnelly and James Copley.  Head over to www.sunderlandecho.com/sport/football/sunderland-afc for all of the latest SAFC-related news and content.

podcast_summary: ‚Äì The owner of the NFL's Miami Dolphins has agreed to a deal to buy the English soccer team Sunderland, the Miami Herald reports. "We are delighted to announce that we have reached an agreement in principle with Sunderland Football Club to buy the club," said Dolphins owner Stephen Ross in a statement. "We are looking forward to working with the board and management team to take the club forward." The deal, which still needs to be approved by the NFL, is said to be worth around $100 million, per the BBC. Sunderland, which plays in the second-tier League One, has been in financial trouble this season.

show_name: Bevin: A Femme Over 40 and her Friends
show_description: Hi, I'm Bevin! I just turned 40 and my friends are my favorite form of wealth! I'm really passionate about self love and empowering other folks to love themselves exactly as they are. I identify as always getting better, not older. I know that the kinder I am to myself the easier it is for me to learn, grow and stay looking a lot younger than I would if I was stressed about aging and the effects of gravity on my body. You're invited to listen to some great conversations with my friends about how we stay resilient, fabulous and thriving! Welcome to the party!  Support this podcast: https://anchor.fm/bevin/support

podcast_summary: ‚Äì Bevin Rose is moving from Los Angeles to Vancouver, Canada, next month, and the tiny house she's renting is making headlines for all the wrong reasons. The 33-year-old radio personality and self-described "sustainable living expert" has been selling her possessions on Facebook Marketplace for the past four months, and now she's decided to put them up for sale in the tiny house she's renting from her mom, reports the CBC. She says she'll be selling most of her possessions, save for her cat, and will be paying about half of what she was paying for her rent. "I'm going down five six and how much my living expenses are maybe even more than that because you know the power bills and the water bills at a house that has a front yard and backyard or not a joke," she says on her podcast. "So I'm actually really excited to go and get to just like really get intimate with that that space." She says she'll be bringing jigsaw puzzles and art to work on while she's in Canada, but she'll be moving into a place with a front yard and backyard, so she won't have to worry about flooding. The tiny house, called The Tiny House, is

episode name: Discussing the Evolution of Hip-Hop Music With Juicy J
creator description: In this podcast I sit down with artist Juicy J to discuss the how the music industry has evolved. As technology advance, the ability to consume content continues to progress as new streaming services arise. More and more control is being taken from the distributors and traditional middlemen of music, and being put into the hands of the artists themselves. 3:20 - The artists make the labels, not the other way around 8:20 - When you pop, do you have a second move? 14:45 - Traditional promotion has changed 21 - If you can entertain and inform, you‚Äôre a GOAT 27:30 - Relevance always matters Did you like this episode? show_description: Welcome to The Garyvee Audio Experience, hosted by entrepreneur, CEO, investor, vlogger, and public speaker Gary Vaynerchuk. On this podcast you'll find a mix of my #AskGaryVee show episodes, keynote speeches on marketing and business, segments from my WEEKLYVEE video series, interviews and fireside chats I've given, as well as new and current thoughts I record originally for this audio experience!

podcast_summary: ‚Äì The Antebellum plantation in St. Francisville, La., has long been known as one of the most haunted places in the US‚Äîand now it's about to get even more famous. The Myrtle's Plantation will be the site of the second-largest haunted house exhibit in the US when it opens to the public in October, the Times-Picayune reports. The exhibit, which will include a re-creation of the 19th-century home's parlor, will feature everything from a mannequin dressed as a 19th-century cook to a model of the home's famous staircase, which was once used to climb to the first floor of the main house. Paranormal investigator Greg Polson, who has been investigating the place for more than 20 years, tells the Times-Picayune that the main house, which was built in the late 18th century by General David Bradford, is haunted by a number of ghosts, including that of Bradford's wife, Chloe, who ran the plantation until she sold it to her son-in-law, George Clark Woodruff, in the late 1800s. She is believed to have been the target of one of the judge Woodruff's most gruesome crimes, when he stabbed her with a large knife

podcast_summary: ‚Äì If you're a fan of the video game Call of Duty: Advanced Warfare, you're in for a treat. Activision says it's delaying the release of the "Call of Duty: Advanced Warfare" video game for the PS4 and Xbox One by a month to give players time to adjust to the new features, the Verge reports. The delay will give players more time to experience the new game mode, "Sundial," which features "new bosses," new weapons, and other features, Activision says. The company says the new features will be rolled out over the next few weeks. "Call of Duty: Advanced Warfare is one of the most anticipated games of the year," the Verge quotes a statement from Activision as saying. "We want players to have time to adjust to the new features before they move on to the next chapter of the game."

episode name: 4 Ways To Start Your Styling Career (Even if you don't live in LA or NYC)
creator description: As an up and coming stylist, it's important to start building your portfolio by doing test shoots. Not only do test shoots let you show off your eye for style, but it will help you be able to book your own jobs down the line. The last thing you want is to intern/assist for 5 years, get asked to style a job by yourself but have no portfolio to show to the photographer/creative director. No matter how many shoots you've helped on, you absolutely can't include another stylists work in your portfolio, even if you assisted. It's their work, period. But have no fear, even if you don't live in a big city like LA or NYC, here are some ways to start building your portfolio.  ---   This episode is sponsored by  ¬∑ Anchor: The easiest way to make a podcast.  https://anchor.fm/app

No Nothing, which she hosts with Bill Rancic, Liu explains that she's been banned from appearing on Ellen DeGeneres' talk show. The reason? She's been posting nude photos of herself on Instagram without permission. "I have been banned from Ellen DeGeneres' show for life," Liu writes on her page. "I will no longer appear on the show or appear on any episode of v. No Nothing until this issue is resolved." She says she's been told she can't appear on the show until she removes the photos from her Instagram account, which has more than 6 million followers. "I have been told by the producers of the show that I cannot appear on the show until I remove the photos from my Instagram account," Liu writes. "I have also been told by the producers of the show that I cannot appear on any episode of v. No Nothing until I remove the photos from my Instagram account." She says she decided to remove the photos from her Instagram account after she was banned from appearing on the Ellen DeGeneres Show last week. podcast_summary: ‚Äì Michigan State basketball player Branden Dawson suffered a season-ending injury in the first half of his team's game against Rutgers on Tuesday, and ESPN's sources say it's more serious than first thought. "He tore his ACL," one source tells ESPN, adding that it's "fair to say" the junior forward will be out for the rest of the season. ESPN's sources say Dawson tore his ACL while going for a rebound and was injured on the same play in the second half. Michigan State coach Mark Dantonio said after the game that he didn't know for sure whether Dawson would be ready for the start of Big Ten play in January, but he said he was optimistic he'd be able to play, per the Detroit Free Press. Dawson is Michigan State's leading scorer and rebounder.

podcast_summary: ‚Äì It's not every day that a kayaker wins a national kayaking championship, but that's exactly what happened in Wisconsin this weekend. The Wisconsin Club Championship on Lake Waveland featured 14 kayakers and was won by 26-year-old Matt Hollenbush, who caught 17 fish over the three-day event, reports the Wausau Daily Herald. It was the second win of the year for Hollenbush, who also won the kayak championship last year. "It's a great way to end the year," he says. "It's a good way to end the summer." The Daily Herald notes that the weather on Waveland was "very tough," with "multiple weather changes" over the course of the day. "I fished with inside a gym all day and ... we got to chat a little on the water," Hollenbush says. "It was a good tournament."

podcast_summary: ‚Äì In 1965, a woman in Warminster, England, told a local journalist about strange noises she heard on Christmas morning, and the story was picked up by the Warminster Journal. Over the next year, more than 30 people wrote in claiming to have experienced strange noises and sightings, and the year 1965 "may very well hold the record for the most UFO reports in England's history," according to a post at Boing Boing. "Not many had any sort of luck with photographing what they dubbed the thing one resident even claimed he took pictures of the thing but his film would review a damaged burnt film role, essentially claiming the thing," the post continues. "Mitted energy that affected cameras affected cameras. Not long after the publication of Marjorie by story many other residents began to share their own experiences upwards of 30 people sent in claims of hearing strange sounds that Christmas morning as well these stories seem to verify marjorie's claims and Arthur Shuttle would begin to compile all the reports." The strange noises and sightings would continue to be reported until the mid-60s, when "the war mr. thing" became a major topic of conversation in the town, according to the Boing Boing post. Now a podcast called The Unsolved Mystery of the Warminster Thing

podcast_summary: ‚Äì If you've ever wondered what it would be like to live like a professional athlete, the Los Angeles Times has just the thing for you: It lists the pros and cons of playing in the NBA. The list includes such big names as Michael Jordan, Scottie Pippen, Steph Curry, Ray Allen, Yao Ming, Magic Johnson, Larry Bird, Carmelo Anthony, and NBA Commissioner Adam Silver. But it also includes up-and-comers like Steph Curry, Ronda Rousey, Ronda Rousey's sister, Chelsea Manning, and Magic Johnson's stepdaughter, Magic Johnson's stepdaughter-in-law, Magic Johnson's stepdaughter-in-law, Magic Johnson's stepdaughter-in-law, and Magic Johnson's stepdaughter-in-law, Jenna Johnson. podcast_summary: ‚Äì It's not every day we get to talk about our pets and robots in the same sentence, but that's exactly what happened in a Reddit AMA over the weekend. The AMA's theme: "Robots: the future of education." It started with a question from one of the AMAs: "Do you think robots should be allowed in schools?" Jordan Sargent, one of the show's co-hosts, answered: "Yes. I think so. Yes. I think we should have robots in schools. Yes. I think they should be allowed to work in schools. Yes. I think they should be allowed to play in schools. Yes. I think they should be allowed to study in schools. Yes. I think they should be allowed to do all kinds of things in schools." The video of Sargent answering the question quickly went viral, with people sharing their thoughts on everything from banning robots in schools to allowing dogs in schools. "Yes, I think we should ban robots in schools," one user writes. "Yes, I think they should be allowed to work in schools. Yes, I think they should be allowed to study in schools. podcast_summary: ‚Äì In 1974, 19-year-old Patricia Hearst was kidnapped by the symbionese Liberation Army and held for two months in a closet in San Francisco. In her memoir, she said she was brainwashed by the group, which wanted to "depose the capitalist system of Oppression." Now, a podcast called Not guilty by Sami Nye and Vanessa Richardson is digging into Hearst's life after her kidnapping, looking at how she became a "self-described urban Guerrilla" and committed crimes with her captors, including a 1974 bank robbery, per the San Francisco Chronicle. In the podcast, they look at how Hearst was able to break away from her captors and join her own cause, ultimately pledging her life to the SLA. "She gained sympathy for and from her captors developing Stockholm syndrome, eventually, she joined her kidnappers cause and pledged her life to the SLA," says Richardson. "She didn't believe any of what she said she did whatever she was told so she would survive before we get into Patricia. Just a quick disclaimer. Vanessa is not a licensed psychologist or psychiatrist, but she's done a lot of research for this show. Thanks Sammy." Among other things, the podcast looks at how Hearst was able to break away from her captors and join her own cause,

podcast_summary: ‚Äì It's been 20 years since the advent of the dot-com bubble, and in a recent episode of the Home Building Hero podcast, host David Bellman takes a look back at what's happened in the past and predicts what's going to happen in the future. Among the things he looks back on: Gas was cheap, Game Boy was the most popular thing, people were listening to the Spice Girls, Google was founded, and the Internet was the first internet phone. "But what's going to happen 20 years from now, it's crazy to think about that," he says. "We have these new restaurants where you basically have casual dining or you can have it delivered to you all those kind of things. Then you start to look at the real estate in the homebuilding market and say that market and that industry hasn't really changed yet. It hasn't really become any different." Of course, there are some things that haven't changed, like the housing market. But there are also some things that have, like the Internet. podcast_summary: ‚Äì It's that time of year again: time to reflect on your New Year's resolution and, if you're like most people, set goals for the new year. If you're like most people, you set those goals and then, well, you don't stick to them. In fact, only 25% of people stick to their New Year's resolutions for at least 30 days, according to statistics cited by Deadspin. That's why Penny Hoarder, a professional bodybuilder and personal trainer, started her own podcast, The Penny Hoarder Show, to help people set and stick to their New Year's resolutions. "The biggest thing I see holding people back from even getting started. It's just that they're afraid to go to the gym," she says in her podcast. "They're intimidated by it." In her podcast, she shares some tips to help people stick to their New Year's resolutions, including: Don't be intimidated by the gym. "Once you go a few times you're going to realize that it's not intimidating," she says. "They're focused on themselves and you could be doing the most ridiculous s--- in the gym."

podcast_summary: ‚Äì A Louisiana State University basketball player has been kicked off the team for an "unsportsmanlike" Instagram post, the Times-Picayune reports. Per a release from the university, freshman Skylar Mays posted a photo of himself with his arms wrapped around a woman on Jan. 6. Mays, a 6-foot-9 forward, is LSU's leading scorer and rebounder, per ESPN. But the Times-Picayune notes Mays also posted a photo of himself with his arms wrapped around a woman on Jan. 13‚Äîthe same day he was kicked off the team. Per the release, Mays posted the photo to Instagram with the caption, "Trying to figure out what to do with my life right now. I can't." Mays' Instagram account has since been taken down.

podcast_summary: ‚Äì Australia's women's hockey team will be going to the Olympics for the first time in 28 years after beating Russia in a playoff for a spot in Tokyo, the BBC reports. The Australians, who haven't been to the Olympics since Sydney 2000, led 2-0 after the first quarter and 3-1 after the second. But Russia scored twice in the last 10 minutes to tie the game and force a penalty shootout, which China won 4-3 after extra time. "We knew it was going to be a nail-biter, and we knew Russia was going to come back," Australian captain Kate Coyne tells the Guardian. "We knew it was going to be a nail-biter, and we knew China was going to come back and score some goals." The Australians, ranked fourth in the world, will be joined in Tokyo by Spain and the Netherlands.
